From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: mund and mund'

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /mʊnt/
  • Rhymes: -ʊnt
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Audio:(file)

Etymology 1

[edit]
Picture dictionary: Mund
Lippe
Zahnfleisch
Zahn
Zunge

Click on labels in the image

Gesicht

From Middle High German munt, from Old High German mund, from Proto-West Germanic *munþ, from Proto-Germanic *munþaz, from Proto-Indo-European *men-.

Cognate with Low German Mund, Dutch mond, English mouth, Danish mund.

Noun

[edit]

Mund m (strong, genitive Mundes or Munds, plural Münder, diminutive Mündchen n or Mündlein n)

  2. mouth of a person
    Synonyms: Maul n, Gosche f, Fresse f, Klappe f, Schnauze f
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Mund [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Mund die Münder
genitive eines des Mundes, Munds der Münder
dative einem dem Mund, Munde1 den Mündern
accusative einen den Mund die Münder

1Now rare, see notes.

Derived terms
[edit]
  • auf den Mund gefallen
  • den Mund verbrennen
  • Honigmund
  • kein Blatt vor den Mund nehmen
  • Kindermund
  • Mundart
  • munden
  • münden
  • Mundflora
  • mundgerecht
  • Mundgeruch
  • Mundharmonika
  • Mundhöhle
  • mündlich
  • Mundorgel
  • Mundpropaganda
  • Mundraub
  • Mundschenk
  • Mundschutz
  • Mundstück
  • Mundteil
  • mundtot
  • Mündung
  • Mundvoll
  • Mundwasser
  • Mundwerk
  • Mundwinkel
  • Schwarzmündige Bänderschnecke
  • Urmünder
  • von der Hand in den Mund leben
  • Weißmündige Bänderschnecke
See also
[edit]
  • Maul, mouth of an animal

Etymology 2

[edit]

From an earlier Munt, from Middle High German and Old High German munt, from Proto-Germanic *mundō.

The retention of /d/ in the combination /nd/ is a signature of northern High German dialects and only becomes widespread after a period in the Middle Ages where the southern reflex /nt/ is favoured in southern writings.

Noun

[edit]

Mund f (genitive Mund, no plural)

  2. (obsolete) hand
    Solange die Frau unter seiner Mund ist, hat sie keinen Nießbrauch an ihrem Vermögen.
    (please add an English translation of this usage example)
  3. (obsolete) legal protection
Usage notes
[edit]
  • Due to conflation with the masculine noun, combined nouns based on this one are also masculine.
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Mund [sg-only, feminine]
singular
indef. def. noun
nominative eine die Mund
genitive einer der Mund
dative einer der Mund
accusative eine die Mund
Derived terms
[edit]
  • Morgenstund hat Gold im Mund (originally in Mund)
Related terms
[edit]
  • bevormunden
  • entmündigen
  • mündig
  • Vormund

Further reading

[edit]
  • “Mund (Öffnung, Lippen, Schlund)” in Duden online
  • “Mund (Gewalt, Macht)” in Duden online
  • “Mund” in Digitales Wörterbuch der deutschen Sprache
  • “Mund” in Uni Leipzig: Wortschatz-Lexikon

  • Mund on the German Wikipedia.Wikipedia de

Hunsrik

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German munt, from Old High German mund, from Proto-West Germanic *munþ, from Proto-Germanic *munþaz, from Proto-Indo-European *men-.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈmunt/
  • Rhymes: -unt
  • Syllabification: Mund

Noun

[edit]

Mund m (plural Munde, diminutive Mundche)

  1. mouth

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Mundfeil

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Mund”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch
